abstract.text: The Apache-I score (APS) was prospectively evaluated during a 6 months period on 1402 consecutive patients admitted in 7 Blegian ICU : neurological (n=171), cardiac (n=284), vascular (n=156), respiratory (n=240), digestive (n=402), renal or urological (n=80), toxicological (n=69) and orthopedic (n=52) diseases. Mean APS was 17.2, hospital death rate 19%. Mortality curve according APS was traced for each pathology and we have determined on each curve the highest APS for a mortality rate of<lO, 20, 40 and 70%. Exc'ept orthopedic disease (Apache~30), whatever is the pa thology, we observed always a mortality rate~70% for APS >30. Also a mortality rate of~-lO% was observed for an APS~IS. However in vascular, renal and toxicological pathology the APS for a mortality rate~lO% was higher, respectively 20, 25 and 30. The highest APS for a mortality rate of~20% and__~40% was quite different between each pathology and varied respectively between~'15 to~30 andS20 toQ30. APS-I was thus very predictive for different pathologies at a score of~15 or>30. But for an APS between 16 and 29, the curves of mortality were different for each pathology.
Our study suggests further evaluation of prognostic score adapted to specific pathology.

Intensive therapy for elderly patients continues to concern health care professionals and patients alike ~nd the appropriate allocation of resources requires some knowledge of outcome. We have studied 209 admissions of 202 elderly patients, aged 75 years and over, to assess the efficacy of such treatment. Records of admission to two ITUs were reviewed over the period of [1983] [1984] . The community hospital ITU had an increased proportion of elderly admissions compared with the teaching hospital -153/922 admissions (16.6%) and 56/1445 admissions (3.9%) respeetlvely,p O.001 -but the distribution of ages (median 79, range 75-100 years) and length of stay of the patients (median 3, range 1-25 days) were similar in the two units. There was a highly significant difference in overall mortality rates between the two ITUs -9.9% in the teaching hospital compared with 17.8% in the community hospltal (p(O.O01). However, there was no difference in mortality when only elderly admissions were considered (13% in the teaching hospital, 21.7% in the community hospital). Elderly patients were grouped into 3 categories: 50 (2~) medical emergencies, gO (40%) elective surgical cases and 72 (36%) surgical emergencies. More elective surgery patients survived ITU admission but mechanical ventilation was associated with a significantly (p (0.01) reduced survival (76% compared with 89% in spontaneously breathing patients). This difference was not evident at hospital discharge (55% v 67%). Overall, 80.7% of elderly patients survived ITU admission hut hospital survival fell to 59%. At three months following discharge, 47.5% of patients were still alive (79% having returned to their own homes, the remainder being in 'sheltered' accomadation). These results demonstrate that age, by itself, should not be a consideration in the allocation of Intensive Therapy resources. PRN is an objective chronometric method for measuring nursing caves. In order $o ascertain which is the proper moment for severity of illnes evaluation in patients admitted to a general ICU~ and so be able to stablish a survival outcome prognosis approach~ 500 consecutive admissions %o our multidisciplinary ICU have been studied. All patients were evaluated according to simplified APACHE system.Scorings were calculated at the admission time and 24 hours later, using for this last calculalion the worst available data for that period. Results: In no case differences were found between the predictive differentiation in survivors and non-survivors by means of R0C eurves~ neither at the admission 9 nor 24 hours later. Conclusion: There is not any predictive advantage in evaluating severity of illness at the admission of the patient in the ICU, instead of 24 hours later, as it has been done up to now, The probability of death increased from 0 to 100%, with increments of SAPS, but the best accuracy (correct classification) was 0.8 at a SAPS of 17. Sensitivity and specificity were less than 0.72 at the best cutoff point (SAPS=13) Thereafter, the 2844 patients were classified in three groups, based on their ICU stay: group I, 0 to 2 days; group II, 3 to 5 days and group III, more than 5 days of ICU stay. In them the ROC curve was plotted. A progressive flattening of the curve, aproaching to the equality line (random), was observed as the ICU stay increased (figure). The areas under the curves (group I=0. 83; group 11=0,74; group 111=0.67) were statistically diferent (p<O.Ol).

We conclude that SAPS correlates with the probability of death, but 20% of the patients are incorrectly classified. Sensitivity and specifi city worsen with longer ICU stays. Hence, the usefulness of SAPS for estimating the risk of death decreases as the outcome distances from prediction. Therefore, periodic applications of SAPS could increase its prognosis accuracy. INTRODUCTION: This study wants to present a new method for the measurement of the FRC during general anaesthesia and in the early post-operative period. MATERIALS/METHODS: Determination of FRC during general anaesthesia with nitrous oxide (N20) and halothane (HAL) was difficult up to now. This was due to the cross-sensitivity of the standard helium analyser to N20 and HAL. To use the inert SF 6 instead of helium as tracer gas in a closed circuit technique, a rapidly reacting infraredanalyser was developed by Siemens Elema, Co. This analyser ist not bound to the patient and can be used independently of a ventilator. We used this new method on a self developed testlung. A total of 10 test-series were carried out, by which a known FRC between 500 and 2000 ml was determined 10 times at each change in FRC. RESULTS: I. The SF6-analyser shows no cross-senfor N20 and HAL. 2. Using the above method, reproducible results were+obtained, showing a deviation of less than -4% from the actual value. CONCLUSION: The results derived from the test lung lead us to believe, that it should be possible to accurately determine changes in the FRC during and after nitrous oxide/halothane anaesthesia. Static compliance is a valuable parameter for assessing lung pathology and customizing ventilator therapy.

A method will be presented which allows the calculation of static compliance in ventilated patients without interruption of ventilation. A microprocessor (Intel 8086) records the flow/pressure signals of the ventilator (Siemens 900 c) and constructs the corresponding PV-loop which is displayed on the screen of an IBM XT. Compliance is derived by determining the slope of the most linear part of the inspiratory and expiratory part of the PV-curve after passing the inflection point. Preliminary results demonstrated a good correlation between the conventionally measured static compliance and the inspiratory compliance of this method.

There is however a significant difference between the inspiratory and the expiratory compliance. It is suggested that the expiratory flow is mainly determined by the higher retractive recoil of the lung as compared to that of the chest wall. Thus expiratory compliance reflects more accurately the elastic properties of the lung. Monitoring lower oesophageal contractility (LEC) has been used to assess the depth of anaesthesia in paralysed patients.

Spontaneous oesophageal activity (SA) and provoked activity (PA) decreases as depth of anaesthesia increases (I). The purpose of this study was to determine if this monitor could be used to evaluate "depth of sedation" in paralysed and ventilated patients on the intensive care unit. Methods : 10 consecutive head injured patients were ~; all were paralysed and ventilated and sedation (morphine + midazolam) was given as indicated on clinical grounds (increase in blood pressure or heart rate, sweating or tear formation). LEC was monitored with an oesophageal probe connected via a pressure transducer to a ANTEC Lectron 301 monitor, and SA and PA recorded. The LEC was monitored continuously the first 8 hrs after admission and then for one hour periods twice a day up to 48 hrs. Results : Only 5 of the 10 patients required sedation. In t-~-6--se~ated patients there was a significant correlation between the amount of sedative drugs given and SA (r = -0.71, p <0.001), whereas PA did not change significantly. In the S unsedated patients, one had continuous SA and made an uneventful recovery; brain death was clfnically diagnosed in the remaining 4 patients in whom no SA was observed, while PA remained present. Conclusions : SA correlates well with the level of sedation and the prolonged absence of SA in unsedated patients suggests brain death. In contrast to anaesthesia, sedation did not influence PA. We feel that LEC is a useful and easy technique to monitor central nervous system activity in paralysed patients in the ITU. The question whether automated indirect blood-pressure measurement devices can replace direct arterial bloodpressure measurement is controversial and thus excites interest. We have examined the following questions: I. How reliable are the values obtained by automatic devices compared to auscultatory procedures or direct blood-pressure measurement in ICU patients? 2. Are there any differences between the devices? 3. What influence does the cardiac index (CI) exert on the results of indirect measurement procedures? In 59 adult ICU patients, values of both the direct and auscultatory method as well as of the devices to be tested were registered concomitantly. Results: There is hardly any difference in the systolic va~ obtained by DINAMAP and ACCUTOR (psyst D: r=0.775; A:r=O.791). ACCUTOR is slightly better for the mean pressure but markedly worse than DINAMAP for pdiast. (pmean A: r=O.757;D:r=O. O77;pdiast A:r=O.563;D:r=O.704) . BOSO yields the best correlations for p syst. and p mean (psyst B: r= 0.842;pmean B:r=O.884;pdiast B: r=0.684) but poor ones for p diast. There is a relation between CI (blood flow) and the systolic values measured by auscultation (mean value from 15 measurements n=56; a=23mmHg; b=-3. 13; r=0 .375 sig, p<O.05): high cardiac indices lead to high auscultatory values of systolic blood pressure and vice versa. Conclusion: Though indirect blood-pressure measurement devices yield plausible values at each measurement, the values differ unforeseeably in both direction and extent from directly measured arterial blood pressure in ICU patients. Thus these devices cannot serve as a replacement for direct blood-pressure measurement.

A number of steps was necessary in the development of a tool for computer assisted diagnosis in hemodynamics. First, theoretical values of oxygen consumption (V02), cardiac index (CI), arterio-venous oxygen difference, stroke index and systemic arterial resistances were determined, using equations corresponding to the physiological curves for V02 and CI as a function of age. They were corrected according to sex, temperature and metabolic status~ as estimated by arterial lactate level. An algorithm, based on the differences between the observed values and those theoretically predicted, was then developed, in order to evaluate loading conditions, cardiac performance and metabolic status. An initial validation was realized comparing the opinions of thre~ experts with that of the computer in 210 patients with hemodynamlc investigation; it showed a poor concordance (39%) between experts. When all three were in agreement, concordance with the computer was 92%. Disagreement was essentially due to different significance attributed to terms and different apreclation of threshold values as a function of age and temperature. After consensus about diagnostic terms and threshold values, a second validation resulted in a total agreement between the experts and the computer.

In conclusion, computer assistance allows a reliable, reproducible and easily available hemodynamlc evaluation. To assess the effects of diazepam in chloroquine poisoning an experimental study was performed in piglets. 14 animals were anesthetized with pentobarbital and mechanically ventilated. Catheters were advanced into the femoral artery for recording systolic (SAP) and diastolic (DAP) arterial pressure, into the femoral vein for drugs infusion, and into the external jugular vein and into the bladder for sampling. ECG was monitored continuously. The piglets were treated with 50 mg.kg-1 ehloroquine given intravenously during 25 min. 7 animals were controls (group C) and 7 were treated with dim zepam given intravenously. 5 min after the end of chloroquine infusion (group D). Diazepam was given as following : 2 mg.kg -I during 2 min. ~hen 2 mg.kg-l.h -I during 25 minutes. All the animals were sacrificated after 1 hour. No statistical difference between the 2 groups was assessed for weight, SAP, DAP, heart rate (HR), T wave or QRS duration before diazepam administration. After diazepam the two groups were different ; in group D the SAP (p < 0.01), the DAP (p < 0.05) and the HR (p < 0.01) were higher, the urine flow increased (p < 0.01) the urinary excretion of ehlorequine (p < 0.01) and the chleroquine clearance (p < 0.05) increased. The T wave was abnormal in 1 from group D and 7 from group C (p 0.01). However no differences could be assess for QRS duration probably because group C improved spontaneously too quickly its QRS duration as no more chloroquine was infused. MONOTHERAPY OF DEATH CAP FUNGUS POISONING WITH SILIBININ. K. Hruby, I. Scholtz, A. Donner; Vergiftungsinformationszentrale, 1090 Wien During the last years drug treatment of death cap fungus poisoning with silibinin proved to be the most promising therapeutic principle causing a significant reduction of the formerly high mortality. In order to avoid unnecessary and possibly harmful polytherapy, the Austrian Poison Information Centre (Pie) has been recommending monotherapy of death cap poisoning with silibinin during the last years. By analyzing the case records collected in summer and autumn 1985 the efficacy of this regimen was examined. A total of 18 cases had been treated solely with silibinin infusions, except for one patient who underwent haemodialysis. There were 15 adults and 3 children, one 6 and two 14 years of age. 11 of the, patients showed severe liver injury with tran~ aminase values up to 7000 U/l, 4 developed a moderate intoxication with maximum transaminase elevations of 2000 U/I and 3 only light signs of toxic liver injury. In all instances gastrointestinal toxin elimination was attempted. 16 patients survived and one with only moderate liver changes died from acute uncontrollable cardiorespiratory insufficiency following aspiration of gastric contents. A second fatality was due to the ingestion of large amounts of deathcap fungi with resulting fulminant hepatic failure. Adding another 8 cases from former years, a total of 24 cases of poisoning from death cap fungus have been treated successfully by silibinin infusions without the usual combination therapy consisting of penicillin and/or thioctic acid in addition to silibinin. This result suggests that the addition of other drugs than silibinin for the treatment of amanita poisoning bears no detectable advantage. there is a lack of information on blood elimination kinetics under normal minute volume after oral intake of chlorinated hydrocarbons.
After oral administration of trichloroethylene and tetrachloroethylene to volunteers, blood elimination kinetics were calculated for normal minute volume.
In 2 cases of acute poisoning with tri-and tetrachloroethylene, respectively, blood elimination kinetics were determined during hyperventilation therapy.
The data clearly support the efficacy of hyperventilation therapy for chlorinated hydrocarbon detoxication:
The elimination half-lives of tri-and tetrachloroethylene were reduced considerably. Additionally, the fraction of the dose which was metabolized and eliminated with the urine was reduced, too.

Carbromal, a sedative-hypnotic drug, is still a nonprescription drug in Belgium. From 1981 to 1985 patients were admitted to the intensive care unit for carbromal poisoning (18 % of intoxications). 56 of them had complete records available for evaluation.

There were 24 men and 32 women; the mean age was 32.5 years. The mortality was 13 %. Parameters were: duration of coma, plasmalevels, chest and abdominal x-ray studies on admission, effect of combined hemoperfusion/hemodialysis and of catharsis. 20 patients (36 %) had pneumonia with a duration of coma of 110.4 hours vs 23.2 hours for patients without pneumonia.
Abdominal x-ray studies showed radio-opaque conglomerates in 27 patients (48 %).
They were negative in 19 patients (34 %) The mean duration of coma was respectively 80.3 hours and 69.6 hours.
Combination of radioopaque conglomerates and pneumonia gives a mean duration of coma of 128.7 hours.

Combined hemoperfusion/hemodialysis only slightly diminish ed duration of coma: 67.6 hours vs 72.3 hours. We concluded that carbromal is still a frequent cause of intoxication in Belgium, with a high mortality and incidence of pneumonia.
Abdominal and chest x-ray on admission are important prognostic factors.
Catharsis is of considerable benefit in the treatment of severe carbromal poisoning.

General anaesthesia has been sho~n to cause lung tissue changes which can be detected by computerized tomography (CT) . They are believed to be compression atelectases. The aim of the present study was to analyse the effect of different anaesthetic regimes on these lung changes and whether they remain postoperatively. Material and methods. Transverse sections of lung tissue were studied in patients by CT during anaesthesia and in the postoperative period. Eight patients were studied during intravenous (thiopentone) and 6 during inhalational (halothane) anaesthesia. The latter patients were studied both during spontaneous and mechanical ventilation. Five of the patients who underwent surgery for inguinal hernia and five patients in whom lapartomy was performed were studied 1 h and 24 h postoperatively. Results. No patient showed any lung changes while awake preoperatively, and all patients developed dependent, crest-shaped lung densities within 5-10 min of anaesthesia The densities comprised 3.4% of the lung volume in the caudal (basal) 5 cm of the lung tissue. No significant differences in the size and distribution of the densities were noted between spontaneous breathing and mechanical ventilation during anaesthesia, or between intravenous and inhalational anaesthesia. The densities remained in 9 of 10 patients i h postoperatively, and they remained in 5 of 10 patients 24 h after anaesthesia. Conclusion. The densities develop whether anaesthesia is Cntravenous or inhalational, and whether the patient is breathing spontaneously or is paralyzed. They may be important contributors to postoperative pulmonary complications.

According to multidisciplinary intensive care organization 6062 patients with critical brain damage were treated in Neuro-Intensive Care Unit (NICU) of Tartu Clinical Hospital in 1958 -1985 Patients suffered from brain and spinal injuries -2101 (36.4%), brain tumours-1097 (18.1%), acute poisoniugs-367 (6.1%), vascular diseases of the brain-1094 (18%), meningitis and encephalitis-343 (5.7%), polyneuropathies-96 (1.6%), etc. The average duration of treatment in NICU was 9 days. The main tasks in the treatment were respiratory care, maintenance of adequate circulation and organ support. Intubation was applied in 2192 cases (36.2%), tracheostomy in 1392(25%) and long term artificial ventilation in 2224 (36.7%). Coma scales, computerized tomography (CT), blood gases, acid-base, water-electrolyte, osmotic and haemostatic balances and serum proteins were regularly monitored and evaluated for prognostic purposes. Lethal outcome and poor quality of life were connected with more severe brain damage on CT and resultant deep coma, persistent hypersmolarity and hypernatremia, severe disseminated intravascular coagulation, mainly with long-term hypocoagulation and increased fibrinolytic activity which prevailed in cerebral venous blood samples as compared to arterial ones. Nultiorgan damage and infection, bleeding disorders and greater mortality were found in cases with DIC as compared to the others. Our data show that the main prognostic factors for patients with critical brain damage are severe brain damage on CT, hemostatic breakdown in local cerebral circulation and severe osmoregulation disturbances. The choice of fluid therapy for optimizing plasma volume in septic shock remains controversial. We investigated the impact of the colloid osmoticwedge pressure gradient (COP-PCWP; as an estimate of the intravascular Starling forces) on extravascular lung water (EVLW) volume. The study design involved fluid replacement with both saline and human albumin solutions (accepted minimum COP: 16 mmHg). Sequential measurements (n=164) of thermal-dye EVLW, COP, and PCWP were performed in 18 patients with severe sepsis. PCWP was within the normal range (9.9 ~3.8 mmHg, mean ±SD); COP (19.6 ±2.6 mmHg) and COP-PCWP (9.8 ±4.3 mmHg) were well maintained. There was no correlation between EVLW (12.9 ±6.2 ml/kg) and PCWP as well as COP-PCWP (p >O.l, Spearman test); however, a positive correlation could be established between EVLW and COP (p <O.Ol). These findings show lacking relevance of COP-PCWP in non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. This gradient is obviously no determinant of EVLW formation in septic states. In accordance with experimental data, colloids might adversely affect transvascular fluid flux and thus enhance fluid overload of the pulmonary interstitium. In conclusion, there is no rationale for maintaining a positive COP-PCWP as therapeutic endpoint for fluid resuscitation if elevated EVLW is caused primarily by a permeability defect of the pulmonary microvasculature. *) Sup@o~ ~ the ~ni~ ~ Health andE~ironmental Protection.

Hypertenic saline infusion has been suggested in the treatment of hypovolemic or burn shock to rapidly expand vascular volume with limited formation of edema. Hypertonic solutions could also improve myocardial performance during circulatory failure.

We studied the effects of continuous administration of hypertonic saline during septic shock in the dog. Thirty min after slow bolus injection of 3 mg/kg endotoxin (E.coli 055B5 Difco), fluid resuscitation was started with hypertonic saline containing 1200 mOsm/l of NaC1 (HT-group, 8 dogs) or with normotonic saline 8 dogs) . Fluid infusion was titrated to maintain pulmonary artery balloon-occluded pressure at control level.

During the ~-hour experiment, the total amount of intravenous fluids averaged 64.5 ~ 7.8 ml/kg in HT-group and 83.6 + 10.3 ml/kg in NT-group (NS). The HT-group had significantly higher cardiac output (5.2 + 0.80 vs 2.g + 0.4 1/min, p < 0.025), stroke volume (36.~ + 6.8 vs Ig.~ ± 3.0 ml, p < 0.05), oxygen consumption (17~ 14 vs 108 ± 20 ml/min, p < 0.05), and lower systemic vascular resistance (1230 + 180 vs 2238 + 410 dynes.sec.cm-5, p < 0.05) than the NT-group after ~ hours. The differences persisted during the last 2 hours but were not statistically significant. No significant difference in arterial pressure was abserved between the 2 groups. In HT-group, serum sodium concentration increased from 147.6 ± 0.9 to 188.3 +--6.0 mEq/l during the experiment.

We have previously shown that transesophageal 2-D echocardiography (TEE) is a useful diagnostic technique for the examination of MV-pts in coronary care units. 1 This study was designed to assess the value of TEE for the examination of polytraumatised and/or postoperative MV-pts with acute cardiovascular complications due to septic shock (phase A -D). We studied 23 consecutive MV-pts (15 male, 8 female; 20 -79 years) in ICU with TEE using a 3.5 MHz (Diasonics) or 5 MHz (Hewlett Packard) phased array transducer at the tip of a flexible gastroscope. No complication occurred in any patient. In all cases image quality was diagnostic but was of higher quality using the 5 MHz probe. 7 pts had no signs of functional or morphologic cardiac disorders. In 16 of 23 septic pts TEE revealed global left ventricular (LV) abnormalities, in 7/16 pts global LV hypokinesia and in 9/16 pts hyperkinetic wall motion (WM). 5 septic pts with hyperkinetic WM were misdiagnosed (pulmonary capillary wedge pressure > 15 mmHg) as having LV failure. TEE findings had therapeutic consequences in 10 cases. Therapeutic results were continuously monitored by TEE up to 3 hours, Pericardial effusion not suspected by clinical means was detected in 4 pts, concentric LV hypertrophy in 3 pts, segmental WM abnormalities in 2 pts and LV aneurysm in 1 of the 23 pts. In another septic pt with hemiplegia TEE revealed vegetations on anterior mitral leaflet. It is concluded that T E E is a complementary diagnostic and save technique for the study of mechanically ventilated surgical ICU pts, It provides valuable functional and morphologic information on cardiac disorders during septic shock and enables the noninvasive monitoring of the responses to treatment. We concluded that i) ARDS was associated with significant low vit E and Se plasma levels, it) The mechanism of this deficiency was probably a vit E and Se consumption during excessive lipid peroxydation, iii) high oxygen concentrations did not affect vit E and Se plasma levels, iv) The potential benefit of vie E and Se administration during ARDS remains to be determine. Recently, the role of activated leukocytes in the oxygen radicals-mediated endothelial cell damage has been evidenced. In this context, lipid peroxidation of membrane phospholipids seems to play a central role, leading to architectural destructuration, to the inactivation of membrane-bound enzymes and to the production of hydroperoxide and other stable compounds, such as malonildialdehyde (MDA).
Cell protection against these pathologic events is mainly due to the antioxydant activity of some enzymes and alpha-tocoferol.

In the adultrespiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) both lipoperoxydation and deficiency of the scavenging system could explain the initial endothelial damage. To test this, 5 patients with severe ARDS were studied in a protocol including the determination of plasma MDA and alpha-tocoferol levels.
Specimens were taken from mixed venous and arterial blood immediately after admission and 6 hours later.

The results have confirmed the contemporary presence of both lipid peroxydation and profound alteration of the scavenging function. Free-radical action on non-respyratory function of the lung could explainthe multi-organ failure often present during ARDS. Under normal condictions, increased peripheral 02 extraction counteracts the decreased oxygen supply; during severe ARDS, this compensatory mechanism is compromised and cellular 02 extraction is only related to its availability. This phenomenon could be consequent to an altered capillary recruitment.

An alterative hypothesis could involve a relationship between the decreased 02 extraction and the derangement of the mitochondrial electron transport chain, as observed during shock condition in humans.

The test this hypotesis, oxyphoretic and cellular aspects in a patient with severe ARDS were studied. Cytochrome C oxydase, succinate cytochrome C reductase, superoxyde dismutase activities and malonildialdehyde levels in muscular biopsies were investigated. In plasma, vit. E and malonildialdehyde values were determined.

The results showed a decreased VO 2 and 02EX and an increased DO 2 during the evolution of the syndrome. Moreover, at the cellular level, mitochondrial derangement and a clear-cut lipid-petoxidation were observed.
Hence, in this patient an altered cellular 02-uptake could be suggested.

Bedside balloon occlusion pulmonary angiography (BOPA) using flow-directed Swan-Ganz pulmonary catheters is a useful technique to study the pulmonary vascular bed in critically ill patients and particularly on patients with Adult Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS). With the aim to confirm the published data by several authors we reviewed the EOPA performed with the teehnzque described by Greene, in 30 prospectively studied patients admitted in our ICU in a three-year period with ARDS of diverse etiologies. All patients received cathecolamines. The overall mortality was 70% ( 21 patients). BOPA detected pulmonary artery filling defects (PAFD) in the 90% of the cases (27 patients) and they were classified as: thrombi (55%), decreased background vascularity (85%) and vessel amputations (100%). We did not find statistically significant differences between the normal and abnormal BOPA groups of patients when we compared the values of highest Fi02, level of PEEP, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) and pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR). None statiscally significant difference was found among the different groups of patients with absent, moderate or severe PAFD. Only when we compared the degree of pulmonary abnormalities seen on chest X-ray (CXR) and the BOPA groups, we found that the mortality in patients with moderate PAFD and patchy air space consolidation (50%) was lower than in patients with moderate PAFD and extensive air space consolidation (87%). In four patients the BOPA diagnosed thrombi in large pulmonary vesels and were treated with high streptokinase (SK) dosage schedule. After the end of SK treatment continuous improvement of the PaO 2 value, intrapulmenary shunt, PVR, PAP and CXR was observed. The BOPA performed 24 hours after the end of SK treatment showed disappearance of the thrombl in all cases. In summary, we think that the BOPA is a useful technique to monitor the changes in the pulmonary vascular bed in ARDS. The suggestion that pulmonary oedema following acute lung injury~ is due to increase in endothelial macromolecular permeability has been tested by following changes in Transcapillary Escape Rate (TER) in patients with pulmonary oedema and comparing them with values obtained in normal controls.

Patients with pulmonary oedema showed a wide range of TER values (6.0 -25% hour) which correlated well with their clinical severity~ as indicated by chest radiography and alveolar-arterial 02 difference~ and were significantly higher than the normal range (3.0 -7.6%/hour, p<0.01). Values for PCWP and CVR showed no significant correlation with TER. No changes in either COP or HC were observed during the study~ indicating that the patients were in a stable state of fluid balance during the TER study.
TER appears to be a useful method of assessing changes in capillary permeability associated with acute lung injury.

body_text.text: Right atrial (RAP) and especially pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) are the common guide parameters used to adjust adequate circulating blood volume (ACBV). We investigated, if intrathoracic blood volume (IVV) may be a better guide for maintaining ACBV i n septic patients. Two groups (8 patients each) of two intensive care units (ICU) were compared. Infusion therapy of ICU l is balanced, whilst a restrictive regimen is performed in ICU 2. IVY -as a side product of lung water measurement with the thermo-dye-technique -is calculated from the femoral artery dye curve (detection with 5 F fiberoptic lung water cath.): CO x MTT, where CO = cardiac output and MTT = mean transit time (dye). RAP and PCWP were measured with usual techniques. The groups were comparable concerning severity of clinically diagnosed sepsis. No difference (unpaired Wilcoxon test, significance p<0.05) between the two groups was found in BW, BSA, PEEP-levels, RAP, PCWP, HR, PVR, and SVR though the mean values of the latter three parameters were higher in patients of ICU 2. Cardiac index with 6.4 I/m 2 (ICU I)/4.6 I/m 2 (ICU 2) and IVV with 36.1 ml/kgBW/24.6 m]/kgBW were significantly different. Moreover, IVY correlated well (12 patients, ICUI÷2, 4 had to be excluded because of intra-renal failure) with GFR (r = 0.70) and free water clearance (r = 0.76) . The respective coefficients r for RAP and PCWP were below 0.35. These results demonstrate the suitability of IVV as an accurate indicator of the circulating volume status. IVY obviously is the only parameter being directly coupled to CBV and different between the ICUs. The lower CO of ICU 2 may be explained by the low IVY. It is concluded, that IVY helps establishing ACBV, thereby being useful for the preservation of renal function and in the differential diagnosis between pre-renal and intra-renal failure. The comparison between groups T and B showed that the patients from the group B were youngers and had a more severe and a more rapid hemorrhage. The etiology of AHS in patients from group B were : arterial wound of the limbs (5), hepatic trauma (7) with hepatic veins rupture (3), splenic rupture (4), ectopic pregnancy (3) and hemothorax (I). Mechanical ventilation was used in 149 (87 %) patients. Pressures were routinely measured at end-expiration from a paper trace. PG ranged from 14 to -10 mm Hg and was evenly distributed around a peak of 2 mm Hg. PG was between 4 and 0 mm Hg in 121 (55 %) patients and between 6 and -2 mm Hg in 173 (78 %) patients. The PG distribution was less related to age than to history or clinical evidence of left heart failure (LHF) or respiratory failure (RF). Of the 29 patients wich a PG above B mm Hg, 22 had LHF and only 3 RF. Of the 20 patients with a PG below -2 mm Hg, 6 had LHF and 8 RF. Critics of the "apparatus medicine" emphasized that the psychic and emotional necessaries of patients during intensive care treatment are undervalued and ignored. Aim of the investigation was finding out how the patient witnessed and judged his stay on ICU.

Patients and Methods: For a period of 15 months a standardized questionaire with 124 questions was presented all patients who stayed longer than 2 days on the own ICU. 2 to 8 months after discharge of the hospital. The reply took place in the domestic atmosphere without controll person and anonymous.

Results: 97 of 128 distributed questionaires were send back (76% return movement), With increasing stay of storage the patients experienced a greater calmness which was expressed by the fact that the feeling of safety increased to 47% and the confidence in the ICU to 55%. At the same time the feeling of restlessness decreased to 13%, of anxiety to 11% and of helplessness to 18% markedly. 85% of the patients pointed out that they owed their life to the intensive care treatment and 90% would go to the ICU again in another life-threatening situation. For the medical convern 50% found a physician as the person of confidence; the others had wished a physician for this function too.
Discussion:

The former patients not experienced the intensive care treatment as impersonal and inhumanof health due to the basic disease and 88% ofthem suffer from it not anypatient gave the statement: never go back to a ICU. The personal contact between physician and patient have to be increased markedly. The patient's search for communication and emotional and psychic safety may be mediated best by a priest or a psychologic educated physician, whereas a psychologist is declined by the patients. body_text.text: Fifty-six patients had haematological malignancy, 9 solid neoplasms and 2 multiple myeloma. Most had acute respiratory failure requiring artificial ventilation. Forty-two patients (63%) died on the ICU, 11 (16%) died on the general ward shortly after leaving the ICU and 14 (21%) survived to be discharged from hospital. Initial analysis of the 22 patients admitted in the first 3 years showed that the immediate outcome (discharge from ICU) was related to the acute physiology score (APS) and the number of organ systems involved. There was also a significant difference between the number of organ systems involved in those who died in hospital and long-term survivors. In the majority of hospital deaths unresponsive malignant disease and persistent ]eucopenia were significant factors. We will present the causes of death, prognostic factors and the relationship between the APACHE II score and risk of hospital death for all 67 patients.

Both for clinical and research purposes these variables are often continuously recorded, conventionally using paper charts on which events are written by the staff. Retrospective analysis of such records involves time-consuming, relatively inaccurate measurements and calculations. We have devised a monitoring system based on the ACT SYRIUS I microcomputer and a 7-channel multi-purpose amplifier system (Gaeltec Research). This allows real time analogue display of central venous pressure (CVP), ICP, BP and the cerebral function monitor.
Heart rate, CVP, BP, ICP and skin/core temperature are displayed digitally.

CPP is calculated and continuously displayed. Events are recorded using dedicated function keys. This data is stored on disc and is always available for review; hard copy can also be obtained. For retrospective analysis, specified events (eg drug administrations or critical reductions in CPP) are automatically located, while a cursor is used to select the precise time at which measurements and calculations are required.
This system is relatively cheap and flexible since appropriate software can be written for a variety of monitoring/research requirements.

Multiergan failure is the most serious complication in diffuse fibrine-purulent peritonitis (DFPP). Additional immunoglobulin therapy is widely accepted, while its efficacy has not been proved in a larger number of patients or even in a randomized study. In a multicenter randomized controlled trial 288 patients suffering from DFPP were included. Half of them received additional immunoglebulin (total 76 g IgG and 5 g IgE) over a period of 5 days. Mortality rate was the same in both groups: 40 to 45 % of patients died. Concerning 46 patients treated in Munich, which were included within the multicenter trial, the results obtained show clearly that additional treatment with immunoglobulins is able tm normalize faster blood concentration of IgG, which was found on subnormal level from the very beginning. That finding, on the other side, did not seem to be of any influence on the outcome of DFPP. Low blood levels of immunoglobulins as present in DFPP should therefore be considered as a single aspect of global immunodepression due to shock or bacterial toxins~ while global immunodepression itself seems to be only a single aspect of multiorgan insufficiency. Appropriate treatment consists in removing surgically toxin and bacteria sources and in stabilizing circulatory function as soon and completely as possible.

We have previously reported on prognostic value of single ABR recordings in post-traumatic comatose patlents (i). In the present study ABR were serially recorded in order to evaluate whether ABR test timing in relation to the injury could affect outcome prediction. 80 ABR test were recorded in 22 severely head-injured patients and the interpeak latency of waves V-I (CCT) was calculated. Two or more tests were recorded in each patient according to the clinical course~ In all cases the duration of the coma was more than a week-17 patients died or remained vegetative: among these 16 showed a CCT>4.48 msec or disappearance of wave Y~ while only one had a persistently normal ABR. In 3 vegetative patients ABR improved progressively during the clinical course and CCT dropped down 4.48 msec. In 4 survived patients the COT was less than 4.48 msec throughout the clinical course. Only one patient with CCT-4.64 on the first ABR test came out of coma, but remained severely disabled. Our results allow us to confirm the close correlation between CCT>4.48 msec and poor outcome previously reported (i) 9 furthermore they suggest that the degree and duration of ABR abnormalities might help to recognize patients who will die and those who will remain vegetative or severely disabled. Head injury is known to cause disturbances of the pulmonary function leading to an increase of the pulmonary right-to-left-shunt and these changes being postulated to be of prognostical relevance. Hemodynamic parameters as Well as EVLWV -determined by the double-indicator thermo-dyetechnique-have been taken b.i.d, for a maximum of up to six days after trauma. No correlation for the EVLWV vs the various hemo~ dynamic parameters could be proven. Our results demonstrate a severe isolated cerebral lesion able to trigger mechanisms to cause a permeability-induced increase of the EVLWV, which is shown to be prognostically relevant. Our results suggest that the combined use of ABR and SEP may improve the outcome prediction and that CTCT might give useful information on brainstem dysfunction~ when ABR cannot be recorded owing to peripheral disturbances of the ear. In 6 Control dogs, 6 on cardiopulmonary byp&ss (CPB) and 6 with previous administration of 0.32 mg/Kg of Ni, we studied the development of ~4D after succesive periods of 60,90,120 and 150" of VF (electrically induced).

The ECG PS lost its initial characteristics and became slow and irregular after 60" in Control VF, conversely, Ni maintained it for more than 100" and the organized PS remained stable on CPB during o]i studied ~iods. So, }~4D development coincided with a PS of VF disorganized and with low frecFdencies; conversely when VF maintained its initial high frequency and PS organization, all dogs Dresented hemodynamic recovery, after defibrillation.

The PS time course during VF seems a reliable method to analyze and quantify the different types of VF. Naso-tracheal-bronchial intubation with two single tubes is better tolerated by children, and it enables the tubes to be fixed very weli, without any displacement occurring. 0ral-tracheal intubation involves fewer difficulties than naso-tracheal intobation with two single tubes, but it is generally badly tolerated by the child, especially when he or she is conscious. A continuous 24 h esophageal pH monitoring was performed in 30 mechanically ventilated newborns with a Memolog 600 system. During 24 h I pH value every 7.5 s was stored in memory. The read-out of data was performed using an AppleIIe computer. The program, in Pascal, was developed by our unit and provides a pH-trend, the moment and duration of GER, and calculates several parameters : the refluxindex (% time pH<4), the total number of GER and those > 5 min.

pH Monitoring was performed in supine position. All babies were fed intravenously, but had no gastric aspiration. Some infants showed no GER at all, in others GER were frequent but of short duration. In + 30 % acid GER were of long duration, indicating a risk for pulmonary aspiration in these neonates. A 2nd pH monitoring, in prone and anti-trendelenburg position, in similar ventilatory conditions, was performed in these infants, and was always within normal ranges.
When technically possible newborns should be ventilated in prone and anti-trendelenburg position to avoid the risk of pulmonary aspiration.

The intrapleural pressure difference represents a force generated by the infant during the respiratory cycle.

Because the intraesophageal pressure reflects intrapleural pressure changes fairly well, it can be used in continuous non invasive monitoring of the respiration in infants. The intraesophageal pressure (IEP) was measured via a Swan-Ganz catheter.

The IEP was determined as the mean of twenty consecutive end expiratory and end inspiratory pressure variations and compared to ventilator pressure recordings. Four known respiratory patterns were found : synchronous breathing, Hering-Breuer reflex, augmented inspiration and active expiration against ventilator inflation. Study of these patterns allowed us to anticipate on the degree of interaction between the child's own respiration with that imposed by the ventilator.
This lowered significantly the frequency of occurrence of pneumothorax and other causes of ineffective ventilation.

Elevated intracra~ial pressure (ICP) in the newborn has a detrimental effect on the brain through impaired cerebral perfusion which leads to ischemic brain injury. The purpose of our repeated measurements of ICP was~ to observe variations of the ICP in the sick neonates and prematures,particularly in those on artificial ventilation with the aim to improve their management in the intensive care unit. Since 1982 25 neonates and infants have undergone CPD in our paediatric intensive care unit. The use of a closed dialysate circuit is essential for this mode of dialysis. Using a standardized treatment protocol it was possible to dialyse even very small premature infants for several weeks. Indications for dialysis were acute renal failure (ARF) (22 patients), otherwise untreatable heart failure with edema (HF) (2 pat.) and severe lactacidosis (LA) (I pat.). Median body weight was 2.8 kg (range 1.0 -10 kg). Median duration of dialysis was 10 days (range 2-89 days).In our experience CPD was a successful treatment modali ty to overcome azotemia, edema, acidosis and related problems of ARF, HF and LA. Complications of CPD were mainly metabolic derangements and electrolyte disturbances as for example hyperglycemia, hypoproteinemia and hypokalemia. Obstruction of the catheter by omentum occured 4 times. Prevention of these complications is possible. Preliminary clearance data of several metabolic substances and electrolytes are presented. 10 of 25 patients (40 %) recovered . Death was due to additional diseases as for instance congenital heart disease, respiratory failure or cerebral damage. In conclusion, CPD gives even very small neonates and infants who are badly ill a better chance of recovery and survival. ~IHOD : A Swan-Ganz catheter 5F was inserted in 9 critically ill children (IO months -7 years). Joreh Klinik f~r An~sthesiologle und operatlve Intensivmedizin und Kinderklinik der Westf~lischen Wilhelms-Universit~t M~nster, Albert-Sehweitzer-StraBe SS, 4400 MUnster A patent ductus arteriosus may complicate intensive care in the neonate due to the negative haemodynamic effeetsand gas exchange. Mainly responsible are pulmonary engorgement leading to considerable cardiac strain and annihilated wind kessel function. A PDA-ligation was performed to shorten the course of distress and recovery, in 15 premature infants with respiratory distre~ syndrome, the mean date of birth was the 29,6 v-week after gestation and a mean birth weight of 1.250 g. With a pulsed doppler the flow velocity (V syst, V mean, V diast) and the pulsativity index in the anterior cerebral artery was determined before and after ligation of the ductus. Preoperatively V diast was significantly (p< 0,005) decreased. The pulsativity index increased compared to the healthy control group. Five of fifteen infants showed a reversed flow in the cerebral artery. In all cases the reversed flow vanished. The mean flow velocity was preoperatively reduced with 6,6 cm/sec, compared to the postoperative velocity of 9,6 cm/see. (p < 0,005). V syst in the PDA group was increased compared to the normal control group, so that the preoperative value was only sllghtly below the normal control group (p< 0,i0). Cerebral blood flow dependent on the left-toright shunt underiies considerable deviations, thus a large PDA may iced to possible isehaemie cerebral damage; the orgar~sm tries to compensate the diastolic steal effect ~ cerebral blood flow by increasing the systolic flow. In adults brain perfusion is maintened on a sufficiently high level even with low blood pressures. In preterm neonates autoregulation of brain perfusion is supposed to be less stable thus increasing the risk for cerebral ischemia and hemorrhage. We measured systolic velocity, enddiastolic velocity, mean velocity, and Pulsatility Index in the carotid artery in 12 shocked neonates (980-3800g) and 41 normal controls. Assuming approximately constant arterial diameters mean velocity reflects brain perfusion. Blood velocity was lower in shocked neonates. The decrease of enddiastolic velocity was more pronounced than that of systolic velocity. Blood velocity correlated with measured blood pressures thus indicating abolition of autoregulation. Conclusion: Abolition of autoregulation of brain perfusion in neonates can be detected by transfontanel Doppler investigations and thus indicates the danger of cerebral ischemia under clinical circumstances. In a two days old male newborn with a body weight of 3200 gm slightly increased breathing rate and pale skin colour was noted. No heart murmur was heard. Chest X-rays showed a small heart but beginning signs of pulmonary edema. When the baby was admitted to our Hospital, 2D-Doppler echocardiography was performed. In subxiphoid coronal and parasaggital views a huge additional vessel crossed the,diaphragm, arising behind the left atrium and connected to the portal sinus. Doppler flow curve showed venous characteristics, and a blood flow direction away from the heart was seen. Additionally a patent ductus arteriosus, a right-to-left shunt at atrial level and signs of pulmonary hypertension were found. The diagnosis of infradiaphragmatic total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage was proven by catheterization. The baby was put on Prostaglandin El, its condition however deteriorated. Rapidly increasing congestive heart failure made a surgical intervention necessary. Pulmonary veins were directly connected to the left atrium, the ductus arteriosus was ligated and the atrial septal defect was closed. Postoperatively no serious problems occured. 2D-Doppler echocardiography was the major tool of proofing anomalous pulmonary venous connections infradiaphragmatically in a newborn with otherwise noncharactcristic symptoms. Cimetidine, a specific H2-antagonist and a potent inhibitor of the gastric secretion was administered in 18 newborns not tolerating oral feeding (abnormal gastric residues and a microor macroscopic bleeding). Abdominal X-ray was normal before feeding was started. Most infants had been in a "stressing situation" before. A control group (15), in comparable clinical conditions, was given a placebo. Oral feeding was always a semi-elemental hypo-allergic diet (AIfare).

Cimetidine was administered in 4 intravenous bolus injections (24 mg/kg/day) for 4 days. Efficacy and possible side-effects of the therapy were studied controlling several parameters. Feeding was tolerated in all treated infants, and only in 4 untreated (P<0.001). In infants treated with cimetidine the gastric emptying time (evaluated by measuring the gastric residue) was markedly decreased compared to the control group. The drug shortened the intensive care period as feeding was earlier tolerated, and diminished this way the need for a central venous catheter.

Rupture of the ventricular septum (VSR) in the acute phase of myocardial infarction (MI) requires accurate diagnosis to decide proper management and indications for surgery. Cardiac catheterization is the usual method to establish the diagnosis of VSR and to quantify the amount of left to right shunt. We tried to assess the use of a combined two-dimensional (2-D-Echo) and pulsed Doppler echocardiography (2-D-Doppler) in the diagnosis of VSR. We studied 4 patients with VSR in acute MI (3 anterior MI and I inferior Ml) by cardiac catheterization and echocardiography (2-D-Echo and pulsed Doppler, Irex III B). The VSR was confirmed by cardiac catheterization in all 4 patients (left to right shunt 47 -?6%). The 2-D-Echo directly visualized the VSR in only 2 of our 4 patients. The combined 2-D-Echo and pulsed Doppler detected unusual flow signals in the right ventricle due to the left to right shunt in all 4 patients. The location of these unusual flow signals coincided with the site of septal rupture confirmed at surgery. Thus the combined 2-D-Echo and pulsed Doppler provides a bedside noninvasive method for diagnosing VSR in patients with acute MI.

Du~ng that time there was a marked increase in the number of patients with spontaneous intracerebr~ hemorrhages( from 10.2% in 1982 to 16.2% 1984 )   while there was a reduction in traumatized patients. Subsequently an increase of the mean age as well as in the length of stay in the ICU was observed ( 82: 3.84 days; 84: 4.44 days ). Length of stay was longest in patients with polytrauma ( 10.5 days ) and in patients operated on cerebellop~ntine angle tumors ( 7.8 days ). Total mortality was reduced from 21.6% to 16.3% during the study period. Reduction of mortality was greatest in patients with spontaneous hemorrhages ( 82: 51.6%; 84: 36.9% ) and in patients with elective operations ( 82: 10.8%; 84: 4.8% ). The occupancy rate raised from 66% in 1982 to 79.8% in 1984. Aggressive treatment of brain edema with barbiturates and pulmonary complicattions especially in elder patients resulted in an increase of ventilated patients ( 82: 23.4%; 84: 62.4% ), Although admissions to the ICU from other hospitals remained constant ( 52% ) more patients had to be transferred to normal units of our clinic after discharge from the ICU ( 82: 55%; 84: 62% ).
